Yeah he also campaigned against Trae's foul drawing behind his back saying he hated it. Even if it's true it's bad obviously from a chemistry standpoint with your star player but also it impacts your ability to win games which should be your goal.   On top of that he was reportedly hard to approach by players and was unreasonably hard on Cam Reddish which might have contributed to his poor season preinjury. Reddish was actually better than Hunter last year.   Overall Pierce comes across like an egomaniac who cared about how the rest of the league viewed him rather than his own team.  Most coaches when they get fired it's like yeah they're disappointing, or maybe they don't fit the FO philosophy, or it's wrong place wrong time, so I never really have hard feelings but with Lloyd Pierce I almost want him to never have a job again. He's young so he might turn it around like a lot of other coaches do but it's just hard to shake how negative he was to a young roster, and it's not like he was "right" to justify such methods.  Like it's telling when Vince Carter as an announcer or legit end of bench players like Nathan Knight are talking about how the difference between McMillan and Pierce is night and day.

Closing out games: We had I think 10+ blown 4th quarter leads under LP  Better offensive scheme: McMillan started using Bogi as a ball handler and offensive playmaker more. LP had him mostly sitting in the corner as a spot up guy. Couple other adjustments as well like taking any kind of ball handling away from Gallo. Stopped giving Bruno Fernando minutes and gave them to Nathan Knight instead.  Belief in players: I didn't put a bunch of belief in this at the beginning of the season but it has become apparent that a lot of players, notably Trae and Collins, did not like LP as coach. They didn't like they way that he refused to give the players credit when they did something well. The change in coaching philosophy under McMillan lead to more even play by the team as the started gaining more confidence.
Hawks deserve a lot of credit. They fought hard and got to the conference finals. But the Bucks just wanted it more.  Shout-out to my man Nathan Knight and Marv Albert.
And Nathan Knight was the second to last active NBA player he mentioned.  Thanks Marv.

We, the Wolves, certainly haven't. It's more a product of our minimal cap space but we made a lateral move healthy for depth across the roster and hope to resign our <7$$ per year role guys (who can be legitimately impactful at times). Not a lot of upside in terms of creative roster building, as our assets seem kinda mismatched in regards to the guys it would make sense to bring in to our roster.   The upside is even our fringe rotational guys have a fair amount of upside going into the season. Jaylen Nowell, Jordan McLaughlin, Jarred  Vanderbilt, (Nathan Knight?), Juancho Hernangomez are all guys that could credibly play better next year than last. How much better is unknown. I personally believe Malik Beasley's play will make GMs reassess his value more highly. Also we're still just riding the high of Anthony Edwards, so life could be worse.
We signed Nathan Knight and McKinley Wright fyi

Timberwolves:  Jarred Vanderbilt is extremely replaceable and not worth $5 million a year.  Jarrett Culver should be ahead of Josh Okogie in the rotation because he has more upside on offense.  A team can never have enough offense, so signing Lauri Markkanen to a deal worth $15-$18 million a year isn't a terrible idea.  If we don't get a PF, Nathan Knight should start at C while KAT moves to PF.  Naz Reid is best suited for a bench role.

I  checked this out on bball ref, and it's unfortunately a little messy to analyze from their platform. Filtering out non-qualifiers leaves out some key guys like Anthony Davis because of injuries either last year or this, but opening it up to all and doing per 36 brings absolute legends such as Nathan Knight and Eugene Omoruyi to the top of the list. So I'm doing some filtering in Excel and will bring any good findings back.
